issues.description: The problem statement's UML defines Pneumatic.raisePressure(int) as returning void, but the solution's Pneumatic interface declares raisePressure(int) returning boolean. This is a cross-artifact method return type mismatch: students reading the UML/description will implement/expect a void method, while the solution interface uses a boolean return type. This discrepancy will confuse students about the intended method signature and return type.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Pneumatic.raisePressure signature with the UML/problem statement by changing the interface method to 'void raisePressure(int pressureIncrease);' in Pneumatic.java (solution and template). Ensure all implementing classes (LaunchedRollerCoaster, LaunchedDropdownTower) implement the void-returning method. Alternatively, if the intended design requires a boolean return, update the problem statement/UML to document boolean as the return type — but prefer changing the solution to void to match the UML.

issues.description: Within the solution repository there is an internal inconsistency: Pneumatic.define raisePressure returns boolean, but the implementing classes (LaunchedRollerCoaster and LaunchedDropdownTower) implement raisePressure with a void return type. This causes a signature/implementation mismatch that will not compile and contradicts the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the solution so the interface and its implementers use the same signature. Change Pneumatic.raisePressure to 'void raisePressure(int pressureIncrease);' and have LaunchedRollerCoaster and LaunchedDropdownTower implement the void method. Alternatively, make all three use 'boolean raisePressure(int)' consistently, and update the problem statement/UML to match — but the recommended fix is to update the solution to match the UML (void).

issues.description: The UML/problem statement declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) with a void return type, but the solution repository's Pneumatic interface declares raisePressure(...) returning boolean. Moreover, the solution's implementing classes (LaunchedRollerCoaster and LaunchedDropdownTower) implement raisePressure(...) with a void return type. This creates an inconsistent declaration/implementation across artifacts: students reading the problem expect a void method, the solution interface uses boolean, and the implementations use void. This mismatch will confuse students about the correct method signature to implement and may cause compilation or behavioral uncertainty.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Pneumatic.raisePressure method signature across all artifacts. Preferably change the solution interface to match the UML/problem statement: declare `void raisePressure(int pressureIncrease);` in Pneumatic.java so it matches the UML and the implementations (which already use void). Alternatively, if the intent is a boolean return value, update the UML/problem statement and all implementing classes to use `boolean raisePressure(int pressureIncrease)` consistently.
